text: Connect a PxrLayer or PxrLayerMixer node here to apply one or more layers.  Note that when a lobe is enabled (e.g. enableDiffuse) in PxrLayer, those parameters for that lobe in PxrLayer will replace and override the same parameters for that lobe in PxrSurface.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Diffuse gain.  This is a multiplier for the diffuse lobe.
Diffuse color.  This sets the color for the diffuse lobe.
Diffuse roughness (OrenNayar model).  The higher the number, the rougher it gets.
Diffuse falloff exponent. This is for Lambertian model only, i.e. when diffuse roughness is 0.
Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals for the diffuse lobe instead of using the normal bump in the Globals. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this diffuse lobe.
If on, the back side will use the regular Diffuse Color. Turn it off to enable a specific Back Color field.

This only applies when Double Sided is on.  Instead of using Diffuse Gain for controlling the intensity of the diffuse transmission, we use Diffuse Transmit Gain.  If it is set to 0.0, the diffuse transmission is off.
This only applies when Double Sided is on.  This sets the color for diffuse transmission.
Artistic mode uses Face and Edge Color and Fresnel Exponent. Physical mode uses Refractive Index and Extinction Coefficient as in most other Bxdfs.
Specular color at 0 degree incidence.  This is the specular color for facing the camera.
Specular color at 90 degree incidence.  This is the specular color for the glancing angle on the edge.
Specular Fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normaly unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

Refractive Index is the dielectric index of refraction for the material.  Channel values for this parameter typically lie in the range 1 - 3.  Since we support 3 color values to capture the spectral effect presets may be preferred over color pickers.

Extinction Coefficient is a second refractive index for the material useful for characterizing metallic behaviors. Channel values for this parameter typically lie in the range 1 - 3.  Since we support 3 color values to capture the spectral effect presets may be prefered over color pickers.  When 0, the material reacts as a dielectric (glass, clearcoat).  When non-zero, the material responds as a conductor would.
Specular roughness.  The higher the number, the rougher it gets. The range is between 0 to 1.  Negative number is not allowed.

Select a specular model.  Both are competitively good models. If you need to match the look to some other Bxdf, such as the Disney bsdf, use Ggx (aka. Trowbridge-Reitz) because most Bxdfs are hard-coded to use Ggx.   Beckmann highlights are relatively sharp, while Ggx highlights have softer falloff. There is no set rule, pick the model which delivers the targeted visual result you are after.

Controls the shape of the specular highlights and reflections. At 0 the shape is circular.  Values from -1 to 1 produce the range of ellipses from fat to tall.  The direction of anisotropy can also be controlled by your model texture parameters and by the Shading Tangent parameter.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals for the specular lobe instead of using the normal bump in the Globals. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this specular lobe.
Artistic mode uses Face and Edge Color and Fresnel Exponent. Physical mode uses Refractive Index and Extinction Coefficient as in most other Bxdfs.
Specular color at 0 degree incidence.  This is the specular color for facing the camera.
Specular color at 90 degree incidence.  This is the specular color for the glancing angle on the edge.
Specular Fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normaly unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

Refractive Index is the dielectric index of refraction for the material.  Channel values for this parameter typically lie in the range 1 - 3.  Since we support 3 color values to capture the spectral effect presets may be preferred over color pickers.

Extinction Coefficient is a second refractive index for the material useful for characterizing metallic behaviors. Channel values for this parameter typically lie in the range 1 - 3.  Since we support 3 color values to capture the spectral effect presets may be prefered over color pickers.  When 0, the material reacts as a dielectric (glass, clearcoat).  When non-zero, the material responds as a conductor would.
Specular roughness.  The higher the number, the rougher it gets. The range is between 0 to 1.  Negative number is not allowed.

Select a specular model.  Both are competitively good models. If you need to match the look to some other Bxdf, such as the Disney bsdf, use Ggx  (aka. Trowbridge-Reitz)because most Bxdfs are hard-coded to use Ggx. Beckmann highlights are relatively sharp, while Ggx highlights have softer falloff. There is no set rule, pick the model which delivers the targeted visual result you are after.

Controls the shape of the specular highlights and reflections. At 0 the shape is circular.  Values from -1 to 1 produce the range of ellipses from fat to tall.  The direction of anisotropy can also be controlled by your model texture parameters and by the Shading Tangent parameter.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals for the rough specular lobe instead of using the normal bump in the Globals. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this specular lobe.
Artistic mode uses Face and Edge Color and Fresnel Exponent. Physical mode uses Refractive Index and offers some absorption properties.
Clearcoat color at 0 degree incidence.  This is the clearcoat color for facing the camera.
Clearcoat color at 90 degree incidence.  This is the clearcoat color for the glancing angle on the edge.
Clearcoat Fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normaly unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

Refractive Index is the dielectric index of refraction for the material.  Channel values for this parameter typically lie in the range 1 - 3.  Since we support 3 color values to capture the spectral effect presets may be preferred over color pickers.

Extinction Coefficient is a second refractive index for the material useful for characterizing metallic behaviors. Channel values for this parameter typically lie in the range 1 - 3.  Since we support 3 color values to capture the spectral effect presets may be prefered over color pickers.  When 0, the material reacts as a dielectric (glass, clearcoat).  When non-zero, the material responds as a conductor would.
Thickness of the clearcoat layer for attenuating through absorption the other active substrates. This method can work in addition to the clearcoatEnergyCompensation approach.

Controls the wavelength dependence of the clearcoatThickness above. The clearcoat medium provides a filter to the substrates. At infinite Thickness, this would be the color observed on the substrates.
Clearcoat roughness.  The higher the number, the rougher it gets. The range is between 0 to 1.  Negative number is not allowed.

Select a specular model.  Both are competitively good models. If you need to match the look to some other Bxdf, such as the Disney bsdf, use Ggx (aka. Trowbridge-Reitz) because most Bxdfs are hard-coded to use Ggx. Beckmann highlights are relatively sharp, while Ggx highlights have softer falloff. There is no set rule, pick the model which delivers the targeted visual result you are after.

Controls the shape of the specular highlights and reflections. At 0 the shape is circular.  Values from -1 to 1 produce the range of ellipses from fat to tall.  The direction of anisotropy can also be controlled by your model texture parameters and by the Shading Tangent parameter.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals for the clearcoat lobe instead of using the normal bump in the Globals. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this clearcoat lobe.

When this is set to > 0.0, it applies energy compensation to the diffuse and subsurface illumination. This is a view dependent fresnel energy compensation.  This effect is visible when we have a low specular face color and high edge color. A value of 1.0 attempts to fully balance those illuminations by darkening them against the specular and rough specular illumination responses. Specular and Rough Specular roughness are also taken into account.

When clearcoat energy compensation is set to > 0.0, it applies energy compensation to all the lobes other than the clearcoat itself. We assume clearcoat is the layer above diffuse, subsurface, and specular. This is a view dependent fresnel energy compensation.  This effect is visible when we have a low clearcoat face color and high edge color. A value of 1.0 attempts to fully balance those illums by darkening them against the clearcoat illumination response. Clearcoat roughness is also taken into account.
Iridescence gain at 0 degree incidence.  This is the iridescence gain for facing the camera.
Iridescence gain at 90 degree incidence.  This is the iridescence gain for the glancing angle on the edge.
Iridescence fresnel curve exponent.  5.0 is a good default.  This is normally unchanged.  If changed, this affects the face and edge falloff.

In Artistic mode, we just set 2 colors. Depending on the iridescence scale factor, we will see N number of 'rainbows'. In Physical mode, we pass the thickness of your thin film in nanometer. The iridescence effect happens when the physical thickness is close to the visible spectrum. You can start around 800nm and increase the value to see the effect.
Iridescence primary color on the hue wheel to start from.
Iridescence secondary color on the hue wheel to end at.
Iridescence roughness.  The higher the number, it rougher it gets. The range is between 0 to 1.  Negative number is not allowed.

Controls the shape of the specular highlights and reflections. At 0 the shape is circular.  Values from -1 to 1 produce the range of ellipses from fat to tall.  The direction of anisotropy can also be controlled by your model texture parameters and by the Shading Tangent parameter.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals for the clearcoat lobe instead of using the normal bump in the Globals. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
Falloff speed from Primary Color to Secondary Color.  Bigger number falloffs slower.
Falloff Scale.  This sets how many times the 'rainbows' repeat.
Flip the hue wheel direction between primary and secondary colors. By default, the hue wheel direction is counter clockwise.  (Not yet implemented in XPU.)
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this iridescence lobe.
Fuzz gain. This is a multiplier for the fuzz lobe.
Fuzz color.  This sets the color for the fuzz lobe.

Since fuzz is a hair-like property, its roughness is controlled by a cone angle in degree which typically ranges from 6 to 20.  It is in fact derived from PxrMarchnerHair’s specular R lobe where it assumes each hair is oriented along the surface normal and is softened by multiplying LdotN.
Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals for the fuzz lobe instead of using the normal bump in the Globals. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this fuzz lobe.

Subsurface profile types. Jensen’s dipole and d'Eon’s better dipole profiles model subsurface diffusion, i.e. subsurface scattering after many bounces of scattering.  Burley’s normalized profile models both diffusion and single-scattering. Path traced implements brute-force Monte Carlo scattering. Only the Burley and path-traced types are available in XPU.
Subsurface gain.  This is a multiplier on the subsurface lobe (subsurfaceColor).
Subsurface color.  This sets the color for the subsurface lobe. (For the Multiple Mean Free Paths subsurface scattering model this is the color of medium-distance scattering.)
Subsurface mean free path scalar distance.  This specifies how far the light travels.  It gets multiplied on the Mean Free Path Color below.

Subsurface mean free path color tint.  This gets multiplied on subsurfaceDmfp to specify how far the light (in the red, green, and blue band) travels on average. (Only used by the Jensen, dEon, and Burley models; ignored for the  Multiple Mean Free Paths model.)

This is only applicable to the Multiple Mean Free Paths subsurface scattering model.  (Not implemented in XPU.) Gain for the short-range subsurface scattering color: multiplier on shortSubsurfaceColor.
This is only applicable to the Multiple Mean Free Paths subsurface scattering model.  (Not implemented in XPU.) Subsurface color for short-range subsurface scattering.
This is only applicable to the Multiple Mean Free Paths subsurface scattering model.  (Not implemented in XPU.) Mean free path length for short-range subsurface scattering.
This is only applicable to the Multiple Mean Free Paths subsurface scattering model.  (Not implemented in XPU.) Gain for the long-range subsurface scattering color: multiplier on longSubsurfaceColor.
This is only applicable to the Multiple Mean Free Paths subsurface scattering model.  (Not implemented in XPU.) Subsurface color for long-range subsurface scattering.
This is only applicable to the Multiple Mean Free Paths subsurface scattering model.  (Not implemented in XPU.) Mean free path length for long-range subsurface scattering.
Anisotropy ('specularity') of the subsurface medium. Higher values makes light scatter predominantly forward.

Controls the depth of light bleed in the subsurface medium. Has the effect of increasing the distance light travels in the medium while preserving fine detail, compared to increasing the Mean Free Path.
Blends a diffuse component into the subsurface calculation. Useful on objects with very sharp edges where dark artifacts can be seen.
If the geometry has self-intersections, enabling this option will track the surfaces so that only the outer-most ones are active for subsurface light transport.
When enabled, light will only exit the surface at perpendicular angles to the surface, and oblique paths are internally reflected. This can help avoid excessive brightness in curved areas.
Tint that is applied at the end of the subsurface computation.

Switch the subsurface computation to a diffuse computation if the dmfp is smaller than the ray footprint.  This gives a useful speed-up for frontlit objects, but gives incorrect results for thin backlit objects where the subsurface scattering would traverse the object. Note that this switch is not recommended for any of the two Path Traced subsurfaceModels, since their random walk also accounts for single and zero scatter events, and is thus not equivalent to diffuse.  For this reason, the Path Traced subsurfaceModels switch to diffuse only when the dmpf is 100 times smaller than the ray footprint. (Not implemented in XPU.)
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this subsurface lobe.

This only applies when Double Sided is on.  Instead of using Subsurface Gain for controlling the intensity of the subsurface transmission, we use Subsurface Transmit Gain.  If it is set to 0.0, the subsurface transmission is off. (Not implemented in XPU.)
Whether subsurface respects surfaces on the otherside.
'Off' - It will ignore surfaces on the other side completely. This is useful to make objects appear thicker than they are.
'On' - Normal mode, where the diffusion happens between the front and the first surface behind it. (Not implemented in XPU.)
'Off' - Simply trace out of the object (default)

'LastHit' - Ignore internal geometry and jump to the last surface * 'AllHits' - Scatter (collect light) on all hits as the ray leaves the object. This can bring additional brightness, at the cost of additional noise. ('LastHit' not implemented in XPU.)
Maximum number of hits to test in 'All Hits' mode. (Hardcoded to 10 in XPU.)

Controls how strongly normals are considered in the subsurface computation. For diffusion sss (subsurfaceTypes 0–4), the followTopology parameter reduces sss from one side to another in concave regions such as crevasses and wrinkles. For path-traced sss (subsurfaceTypes 5–6), the followTopology parameter reduces sss paths being blocked by backsides behind a surface, but also reduces sss from one side to another in convex regions such as ridges and ears.
Single scatter gain.  This is a multiplier for the single scatter lobe.
Single scatter color.  This is the color for the single scatter lobe.
Single scatter mean free path scalar distance. This specifies how far the light travels.  This gets multiplied to the Mean Free Path Color below.
Single scatter mean free path color.  This specifies how far the light travels in the R, G and B spectra.
Gain for direct illumination from the other side.
Tinting color for the direct gain.
If on, illuminate on both sides of the surface for this single scatter lobe.
Whether single scatter respects surfaces on the otherside.
'Off' - It will ignore surfaces on the other side completely. This is useful to make objects apear thicker than they are.
'On' - Normal mode, where the scattering happens between the front and the first surface behind it.
'Off' - Simply trace out of the object (default)

'LastHit' - Ignore internal geometry and jump to the last surface * 'AllHits' - Scatter (collect light) on all hits as the ray leaves the object. This can bring additional brightness, at the cost of additional noise. (Not implemented in XPU.)
Maximum number of hits to test in all hits mode.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Control the continuation ray mode for direct gain.
'FirstHit' - Simply trace to the next surface (this is tied to considerBackside)

'LastHit' - Ignore internal geometry and jump to the last surface * 'AllHits' - Scatter (collect light) on all hits as the ray leaves the object. This can bring additional brightness, at the cost of additional noise.
A tint applied to illumination before being scattered by subsurface or single scatter.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Diffuse roughness (Oren-Nayar model) to be applied for subsurface or single scatter.  (Not implemented in XPU.)

Subsurface and single scatter unit length.  It is a multiplier on Mean Free Path Distance.  Mean Free Path Distance is often measured in millimeters.  If the scene is modeled in some other scale, Unit Length should be set accordingly.  The default value of 0.1 is appropriate for scenes modeled in centimeters and Mean Free Path Distance measured in millimeters.
Refraction gain.  This is a multiplier for the refraction.
Reflection gain.  This is a multiplier for the reflection.
Refraction color.  This sets the color for the refraction.
Roughness for glass reflection.  Also used for glass refraction unless a separate glassRefractionRoughness value is specified.  Bigger number is rougher.
Roughness for glass refraction.  Default is -1.0.  If this number is negative, the glassRoughness value will be used for refraction. Bigger number is rougher.

An additional roughness parameter for glass refraction.  Default is 0.0.   If this number is 0.0, the glassRefractionRoughness value will be used for refraction. Bigger number is rougher.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Controls blending weight between the two lobes,  Refraction Roughness and Refraction 2 Roughness. Value of
means only the Refraction Roughness lobe is active and value of
means only the Refraction 2 Roughness lobe is active.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
This sets the color for the Refraction 2 Roughness lobe (as a multiplier on Refraction Color for the samples generated with  Refraction 2 Roughness).  (Not implemented in XPU.)

Controls the shape of the specular highlights and reflections. At 0 the shape is circular.  Values from -1 to 1 produce the range of ellipses from fat to tall.  The direction of anisotropy can also be controlled by your model texture parameters and by the Shading Tangent parameter.
Controls the anisotropy direction. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.  (Not implemented in XPU.)

Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals for the clearcoat lobe instead of using the normal bump in the Globals. Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
If on, enables the use of manifold exploration algorithms (such as manifold walk and caustic connection strategies) on this surface.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Index of refraction for Manifold Walk. (If negative, internally it will be set to glassIor.) (Not implemented in XPU.)
If on, correctly split energy according to IOR between reflection and refraction, but do not bend the ray in refraction (simulating a double pane of glass with a single pane).
If on, forces the fresnel IOR weighting to be off (which has the side-effect of turning reflection off). This is sometimes desirable for extracting a pure refraction distortion mask for compositing.

If on, even if the integrator has Accum Opacity on (where the intention is to generate a partial alpha from refraction for compositing), the alpha will be locally forced to 1.0 after refraction. (Not implemented in XPU.)
If on, the material will block other volumes, including any intersecting volume geometry.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Use volume aggregate as interior.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Color of the particles in the volume.
Extinction coefficient that controls how light is absorbed as it travels through the volume. Higher values will block more light.
Controls the directionality of the scattering (1: forward, -1: backward, 0:isotropic).
Controls the secondary directionality of the scattering (1: forward, -1: backward, 0:isotropic)
Glow coefficient that controls how much light is emitted from the volume.
Global max extinction used by volume tracking.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
If enabled, the interior volume can be overlapped with other volumes to create combined effects.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
Glow gain.  This is a multiplier for the glow.
Controls the glow (incandescence) of the material.

Connect a PxrBump node here if you need bump or normal-mapped normals.  Only valid when provided as a texture/connection.  If the individual lobe’s bump normal is set, this global bump be ignored for that lobe.
Shadow Bump Terminator. Hide the abrupt shadow terminator line when strong bump or normal maps are used.
Shadow computation mode. 'Shade and shadow color' mode evaluates the shader for the opacity color for computing the shadow color.

Connect a mask function here to apply a cutout pattern to your object.  Presence is defined as a binary (0 or 1) function that can take on continuous values to antialias the shape.  Useful for modeling leaves and other thin, complex shapes.
If on, allows the manifold exploration algorithm to start on this surface. (Not implemented in XPU.)

The Option 'shade' 'roughnessmollification' increases roughness after hitting curved and/or partially rough objects. (The Option used to be an integrator parameter called 'specularCurvatureFilter'.) This clamp parameter can be used to limit the effect of the roughness mollification for particular surfaces.  (Not implemented in XPU.)
User color provided to the bxdf to be stored in the 'UserColor' user lobe, typically user4 (U4).
Utility patterns are evaluated but their results are not used by the bxdf. This is where input AOV is connected.
